title: For Sale:  Very Fine Condition and Early Colt Government Model 1911A1 .45 c. 1928
postcontent:
This is a very fine and near mint condition, all original Colt Government Model 1911A1 Pistol from 1928. The serial number on this Colt is C153591, which was manufactured at the Colt Plant in Hartford, Connecticut in 1928. The serial number range for Colt Government Model Pistols in 1928 was C152,000 to C154,999, which is a small production run of only 3,000 pistols that year. It is important to note that there was no military 1911A1 production from 1925 until 1936, only commercially available Government Models in the 1911A1 configuration, so the only examples for the Colt collector from this decade are these Government Models. Colt took the opportunity to not only capitalize on the popularity of the pistol based on its service in WWI, but to also continue to refine the design for any future military contracts. Colt's commercial production of the 1911 began just after the military contracts were manufactured. The first fifty Colt Model 1911 Pistols were crated and shipped on January 4, 1912. The first commercial Government Models 1911, serial number C1, was shipped from the Colt factory on April 13, 1912. When Colt began to experiment with design modifications following WWI, they did so with the commercially available Government Model 1911. The first of what became the 1911A1 pistol rolled off the Colt production line in October 1923, at serial number C135,000. The newly designed Colt Government Model 1911A1 incorporated the finger relief cut on the frame/receiver, the arched and checkered mainspring housing, and the fully checkered walnut stocks. The first military Colt 1911A1, which was known as the Transition Model, began at serial number 700,000 in 1924 and only 10,000 of this model were produced before military pistol contracts ceased for over a decade. The next military contract Colt 1911A1, serial number 710,001, would not be manufactured at Colt until 1937.

The Receiver (sometimes referred to as the Frame) on this pistol retains 99% of the original Colt high quality "dull" blue finish. As both Charles Clawson and Joe Poyer note in their respective treatises on the Colt 1911 Pistol, the "dull" blue finish used by Colt was only slightly less reflective than the earlier glistening "oil finish." Once the finish was applied, the worker polished the blued steel to what was known as a "fine finish," which is the polishing stage just below the "oil finish." As Poyer notes, the new "dull" finish was "dull only in comparison to the high gloss "oil" finish, which was discontinued on the Colt Government Model around serial number C10,000. The right side of the Frame has the serial number "C153591," with the correct vertical, sans serif "C" and the numbers are the ornamental serif font that slants to the right. Colt used this font format for Government Model serial numbers from serial number C130,000 to C198,000. The serif "C" had previously been used but it was dropped by Colt for a short period around serial number C130,000 and did not reappear again until serial number C170,001. The "GOVERNMENT MODEL" stamp is sans serif and is correctly to the rear of the slide stop in hole. Both the Government Model nomenclature and the serial number stampings are as crisp as the day they were first made.

At the top right portion of the Trigger Guard flat on the right side of the Receiver is the crisp, sans serif "51" stamp, which is the Colt Assembler's Mark. The Assembler's Mark in this location on Colt Government Model 1911A1s began at serial number C130,000. The top left side of the Trigger Guard flat on the left side of the Receiver has a crisp "1" Commercial Inspection Mark above the crisp, stylized "V" and "P" stamp set inside an inverted triangle, which is the Colt Verified Proof stamp. The top of the Receiver, just to the right and rear of the disconnector at the 5 o'clock position is the correct sans serif "S" stamp, which is the Colt Commercial marking for "sales," as opposed to the "G" stamp for government contracts. Just above the "S" stamp, at the 3 o'clock position, is the Colt Commercial Inspection Marking. The Receiver on this Colt is simply beautiful. The interior portions of the Receiver retain nearly 100% of the original blued finish with virtually no wear at all. The internal portion of the Receiver at the recoil spring shroud retains 100% of its original blued finish with no wear noted. The internal wall that serves as the facing portion of the Receiver for the Grip Safety and Mainspring Housing retains 100% of its original blued finish. The barrel recess at the front of the Receiver retains 100% of its original blued finish. The Feed Ramp is correctly polished to the white and shows no scratches from feeding or any wear whatsoever. The area around both the top and bottom side of the disconnector hole retains 100% of its original blued finish with no wear noted.

The area of the Receiver that is under the grip panels when they are installed retains 100% of the original blued finish with slight brown discoloration in places, which is probably from the original oil finish on the stocks. The front grip strap and trigger bow, areas that ordinarily show the most wear on 1911 pistols, both retains 100% of their original blued finish with minor surface scratches seen on close examination but in remarkable and beautiful condition. The Ejector is solidly in position and retains 100% of its original finish with no wear noted at all on its leading edge, which is another indicator that this pistol remains unfired since it was manufactured. All four stock screw bushings are securely screwed to the Receiver and all retain 98% of their original blued finish. The Plunger Tube on the upper left side of the Receiver retains 98% of its original blued finish. The rounded ends of both the Slide Stop Plunger and the Safety Catch Plunger correctly remain in the white and are polished bright. There is a very faint slide catch line on the left side of the Receiver arcing downwards towards the left side finger relief cut but it is not deep and appears to only go through the blued finish layer. The only wear of note on the Receiver is a small area just above the finger relief cut on the right side and a small area just above the right side trigger guard. The rest of the Receiver is pristine and truly exhibits the fine finish and lack of wear consistent with an unfired weapon.
